clips.Description: What does the character do for a living? Show the audience the most important element of the character. This element should fill at least 50% of the frame.
clips.Goal: Depict something noteworthy about the character.
clips.Tip: If you are too close to the action, your phone’s camera may not be able to focus. Keep the camera at arm’s length from your subject.
clips.Title: Signature

clips.Description: This shot should be wide enough to depict the character’s complete action. The character should fill 20% of your frame.
clips.Goal: Show the character engaged in her environment.
clips.Tip: Keep your character on one of the vertical lines to frame your shot properly.
clips.Title: Action

clips.Description: Show the audience who your character is, build a connection between the viewer and subject. The character should fill at least 50% of the frame.
clips.Tip: Use the eye-line to frame your shot properly.
clips.Title: Character

clips.Description: Ask open-ended questions. Decide your questions based on the type of source you are interviewing. The character should fill at least 30% of the frame.
clips.Goal: Ask the character to tell you a story.
clips.Tip: Place your character on one side of the frame, frame your shot to show something else important to the story on the other side.
clips.Title: Interview

clips.Description: Environmental video may indicate the country or an ethnic or religious element. Include landmarks or other location specific information. The character will fill no more than 10% of the frame.
clips.Goal: Environmental clips help the audience understand where your story takes place.
clips.Tip: Place your camera directly in front of the primary location you are filming. Landmarks help the audience understand their location.
clips.Title: Environmental
